description.narrative: Support the Parliament as law making and oversight body to enable them to perform core functions to meet the provisions of the new federal constitution.
independent political entity
Elections - elections

1). # of MPs and parliament secretariat staff with enhanced capacity in law making and oversight functions 2) A comprehensive need assessment completed for Parliament 3) Strengthen capacity of the parliamentarians to implement Agenda 2030 4) Enhance parliamentary outreach through media and other innovative approaches 5) # of knowledge products developed and disseminated 6) # of Bills reviewed by committees in participatory manner 7)# of oversight inquiries conducted by committees in an inclusive and participatory manner 8) # of people educated on new constitutional provisions

comment.narrative: Zero

1) At least two bills reviewed and feedback submitted to Parliament members 2) Public awareness among at least 2000 people on newly promulgated constitution conducted 3) Develop a framework for oversight function 4) Conduct a comprehensive need assessment of parliament 5) Strengthen capacity of parliamentary committees through 5 Interaction meeting/workshop on lawmaking, policy analysis and oversight functions 7) Foster implementation of SDGs in Nepal by creating a parliamentary forum 8) Enhance parliamentary outreach through media and other innovative approaches (accounting for the marginalized groups)

1. Eleven Bills (Election-3, Constitutional Commissions-6, Disability-1 and wildlife -1) were reviewed and expert support extended at various levels of Committee work (public consultations, committee deliberations, discussion with stakeholders etc.). Such feedback were reflected in form of amendment proposals by the Parliamentarians and contributed to make informed decision during committee deliberations.
2. Against the need of the political understanding among the public and thereby create ownership and better uphold the constitutional arrangements, a civic education campaign was launched which reached out to 700 people (38% female) through 10 direct interaction events, and another 15 million through 90 FM radios across the whole country. 3. An oversight framework developed in order to enhance the core oversight function of the parliamentarians. The tool, consisting of the international best practices, was also shared to 13 MPs from different committees and the secretariat staff. 4. A comprehensive need assessment of the Parliament completed and accordingly the project document revised.
5. A total of 6 interaction/workshop events on various themes completed with five Parliament Committees in which over 100 MPs and 35 CSO representatives from different walks of life participated allowing them to provide their feedback and raise questions/propositions on the bills, development and oversight issues, among others.
6. Three oversight visits for parliamentary committees conducted. Of them, Environment Protection Committee including chair and 8 members visited a religious site in Triveni, Nawalparasi in order to inquire about cabinet's reportedly controversial decision of granting land of the national park to the Hindu Temple. Field oversight helped the Committee to account for the first- hand information from the stakeholders and reach a conclusion that the media-induced controversy over the cabinet decision was not true as reported. Likewise, Women, Children, S

1. Develop a strategy plan for preparation of establishing parliaments at national and provincial level 2. Organize 9 events for 100 MPs and 30 staff as part of continuous learning/capacity building 3. Strengthen capacity of the parliamentarians to implement SDGs (Agenda 2030) 4. Review 6 bills and ensure public engagement in lawmaking 5. Strengthen Parliamentary oversight through 6 oversight missions, knowledge products and public hearing 6. Enhance parliamentary outreach through media and other innovative approaches

1. A transitional plan on setting up of provincial parliaments was developed by bringing in international experiences. The plan offered detail insights to various stakeholders(including MPs, Parliament Secretariat, and donors)on human resources, infrastructural facilities, and finances required thereof.
2. Approximately 180 MPs (49 % Female) and 99 Parliament Secretariat staffs ( 18 % female) enhanced their skills and knowledge from over two dozens of trainings/ workshops and knowledge products on law making, oversight, leadership, and parliament report writing, among others. Handbooks on SDGs, Climate Change Finance, and Oversight, Bill Review tool and Template Rules of Procedure for Provincial Assemblies, Induction Package for MPs, including the e-learning modules are the key products developed during the reporting period.
3. Project continued to engage the Informal Group of MPs on SDGs for promoting the institutionalization of SDGs in the parliament. To this end, publication/translation of knowledge products and organizing workshops with international experts was a major work. The continuous engagement with parliamentarians has helped to reinforce the need to create a formal oversight body in the parliament.
4. Ten bills (including Commission Bills, Cooperative Bill, anti-torture bill, Medical Education, and Civil code, among others) were reviewed and expert support extended at various levels of Committee work. Result of such engagement helped MPs to register amendment proposals on the Bills and to take informed decision during committee deliberations. In order to ensure peoples participation in the lawmaking, public consultation programmes were also conducted in which, more than 369 people (16 % female) provided their inputs in person.

Elections - elections

1. % of men and women (16+) registered by Election Commission of Nepal with photographs and bio-metric profiling 2. Operational plan for elections developed 3. # of people sensitized on on electoral system and processes through Electorate Education and Information Center at national and sub-national levels 4. New Strategic Plan ( 2015- 2109) of the ENC developed and implemented 5. Inclusive, participatory and credible elections organized 6. Gender policy of the ECN developed and implemented

comment.narrative: 1. As of December 2012, 10.9 million voters registered with photographs and bio- metric profiling 2. Election Commission does not have an operational plan for the forthcoming elections 3. 3000 citizens , particularly youth and first time voters, sensitized on electoral system and processes through EEIC at national and sub-national levels 4. New Strategic plan of the ENC ( 2015- 2019) yet to be developed 5. No data available 2. 1500 people sensitized on electoral system and processes through EEIC 4. New Strategic Plan ( 2015- 2109) of the ENC developed and implemented 5. No data 6. Gender policy of the ECN to be developed and implemented

1. An additional 531,546 citizens of 16 years and above were registered on voters roll with photographs 2. An additional 4,288 citizens, particularly youth and first time voters, were sensitized on democracy and elections through EEIC 3. A total of 607 Social Studies teachers benefited from trainings on elections and democracy. 4. Key knowledge products produced 5. Targeted interventions organized for people with disability

1. An additional 531,546 citizens of 16 years and above were registered on the biometric voters roll in 2016, accumulating a total of 13.8 million citizens. An additional 2.9 million citizens have been registered since the beginning of the project starting 2013.
2. The mobile Electoral Education and Information Center (EEIC) was launched, through which the ECN was able to reach out to citizens residing in remote parts of Nepal. An additional 4,288 citizens, particularly youth and first time voters, were sensitized on democracy and elections through EEIC, accumulating a total citizen sensitized to 26,288. The EEIC was established in 2012.
3. In order to enhance voters meaningful participation in future elections, the ECN reached out to almost 6 million citizens through print and electronic media sensitizing citizens about elections, electoral provisions in the new constitution and democracy.
4. In order to make the electoral process more inclusive and in line with the principle of leaving no one behind, targeted programmes were organized for visually impaired citizens, people with hearing disability and senior citizens.
5. A total of 607 Social Studies teachers benefited from trainings on elections and democracy. These trained teachers shared that they were able to impart clearer message to higher secondary school students, as the theme of elections and democracy is part of high school curriculum. The ECN, with TA from ESP, has so far trained more than 1000 Social Studies teachers since 2015.
Key knowledge products produced are as follows: o Training Manuals for people with hearing disability o Training Manual for the visually impaired o Training Manual on Administrative Leadership o Resource book on Electoral Education for Social Studies Teachers o "Electoral Provision in the Constitution of Nepal Handbook in Nepali and English o Report on SAARC Regional Workshop on Electoral Dispute Resolution and Electoral Justice (21-22 July 2016).

1. An additional 1.2 million voters registered on biometric voters roll 2. Over 30,000 voters sensitized on electoral system and processes contributing to over 70% of voters' turnout in elections 3. Targeted capacity building programme conducted for potential women candidates contributing to at least 40% of women's representation in local governments and 33% at federal and state assemblies 4.Targeted voter education programmes organized for people with disability 5. Conduct of an inclusive and credible elections with reduced international assistance

1. An additional 1.6 million voters registered in 2017 on voter rolls, making a cumulative registered voters to 15.4 million. The voter rolls with photographs were used in three tiers of elections held in 2017 that contributed to enhanced credibility of the electoral process through an easy identification of voters, avoiding multiple and proxy voting.
2. In addition to a campaign through media, approximately 200,000 voters directly sensitized on electoral system , process and voting procedures in the local level elections, that contributed to 74% of voter turnout. Similarly, the nation wide campaign continued for federal and provincial elections, that contributed to 66% of voter turnout
3.Targeted media campaigns, trainings and national conference conducted on women's political participation. Approximately 52, 268 potential women candidates directly sensitized on elections and constitutional provisions through training cascades and orientations , it contributed to over 44% of women representation in local governments. Out of 52,268 potential women candidates sensitized, around 4,000 became candidates and 1,011 won the local elections. Similarly, for women voters and candidates . As a result of which 44% of women got elected in local elections.
4. Voter education training manuals and training cascades were organized for people with disability before all three tiers of the elections. Similarly , targeted Public Service Announcements were developed and broadcasted for this segment of the society and to leave no one behind from exercising their electoral rights
5. The Election Commission ( ECN) conducted three tiers of elections in five phases with full ownership and leadership and with reduced international assistance .Compared to 2013 Constituent Assembly elections, the assistance provided by UNDP to ECN in the local elections was mostly technical with reduced operational assistance. The support was further downsized in the Provincial and Federal elect

comment.narrative: Resident Coordinators Annual Reports UNCT Annual Workplans and UNCT Annual Report UNDAF Annual Report and ME Framework

Undertake evaluation of the UNDAF 2013-2017, prepare Common Country Analysis and the Comparative Advantage Survey as well as consultations with Government, Civil Society and development partners. Development of ERP Phase 1 and 2 for Disaster Risk Preparedness in collaboration with OCHA ROAP. Implementation of the DAO principles for the UNCT, support localization of the SDGs. Use field-based information to inform polices, programming and advocacy points. Develop common advocacy points for the UNCT and development partners to use on key issues.

UNDAF evaluation was undertaken and the results used to inform the UNDAF 2018-2022. The UNCT prepared the Common Country Analysis and undertook the Comparative Advantage Analysis,which was used to inform the formulation of the UNDAF 2018-2022. Three consultationswere undertaken with the Government of Nepal, civil society and development partners. The HCT and clusters all worked to update the ERP Phase 1 for floods and with the support of OCHA ROAP developed the ERP Phase 2 for another big earthquake. The response plan was based on seismic risk scenarios developed in collaboration with Durham University. A CERF proposal to mitigate the consequence of the drought in the Karnali Region was prepared and awarded US$ 1.9 million. The UNCT increasingly implemented the DAO principles. This included deciding to adopt the Business Operation Strategy and roll it out together with the UNDAF 2018-2022. The communications group was also reinvigorated with a focus on communicating on the SDGs. The UNCT kickstarted the implementation of the MAPS for UNCTs on the SDGs with a retreat and used this to develop various strategies to ensure engagement. The ME and SDG working contributed to ensure that the national ME framework was SDG informed. The field based information was used to inform policies and programmes. For example analysis on infringements and challenges to operational space for development (i..e political pressure and donation demands), which was used to inform advocacy efforts. At the local level the Field Coordination Offices assisted in coordination. Common advocacy points were developed for example to ensure a dedicated fuel supply to the logistics cluster to bring support to the earthquake affected areas during the border obstructions. Another area of advocacy was on ensuring a victim centric approach to the transitional justice as well as ensuring that the legislation is brought in line with international standards.

Developing the UNDAF 2018 - 2022 with the Government of Nepal. Strenghtened implementation of DAO principles as well as QCPR 2016 SOPs. Support the localization and implementation of the SDGs. Updating of ERP Phase 1 and 2, as well as response to humanitarian needs when they arise. Use field based information to inform policy, programmes and advocacy points. Coordination of UN support to federalization and decentralization process.

UNDAF 2018-2022 developed with strong collaboration from UNCT members as well as technical outcome groups taking into account the four programming principles and ensuring that the UNDAF has the SDGs at the center. Regular briefings and discussions held at the UNCT on the roll out of the QCPR as well as reform initiatives taken at HQ level and the implications at country level. Communications Strategy adopted for the UN Communications Group. Common budgetary framework to be developed. Flood response to the floods in August 2017 coordinated, situation reports prepared, CERF application submitted and Joint Response Plan developed on behalf of the Humanitarian Country Team and clusters. Field information used to understand the dynamic and changing local context, in particular in light of the decentralization and federalization process.Analysis based on observations of the changing context both prior and after the first local elections in 20 years.

This would lead to a longer term Government-led plan of action.

comment.narrative: Following the earthquake of 2015 work at project and progamme level continues under the NRRC 5 Flagship format. The inevitable focus on response and recovery from the earthquake has not permitted the necessary national level dialogue on resilience and DRR following Sendai. NRRC was to have reconsidered priorities at the end of 2015 with a view to resetting the agenda from 2016 onwards. It is expected that this will be possible only from the second quarter onwards of 2016 at the earliest.
Development of a national urban resilience strategy, National Plan of Action for Safer Building Construction and support to emergency preparedness simulations.

Impact Study on Flagship 4 minimum characteristics for CBDRM was completed and a workshop with all stakeholders was held to review findings. Development of the Urban Resilience Strategy was supported by NRRC, and continued after the project's closure. A workshop was held in August 2016 to develop district plans to implement that National Plan of Action for Safer Building Construction.
Project was closed in September 2016, hence there are no targets or results for 2017. New project (00101729) was created as a successor project for CFP Phase II.

comment.narrative: 42% of survey respondents reported having received the information they needed to access support and/or services. 18% of survey respondents expressed that their recovery and reconstruction needs were being met.
Development of new thematic survey questionnaires to cover three, identified reconstruction themes and beginning survey implementation, as well as enumerator training.

Due to a delay in fund release from the donor, full activities were delayed until the beginning of 2017. Consultations on the questionnaires and finalization of the tools to be used were completed in 2016; however, training and implementation started only in January 2017. However, in order to continue feedback collection project team members conducted qualitative research through focus group discussions and developed feedback reports based on this to ensure no interruption in the provision of feedback to humanitarian partners.

Improvements in community perceptions on all thematic issues, particularly reconstruction, and initiation of closing the feedback loop activities, demonstrating results in communities issues being resolved and an overall improvement in satisfaction with the reconstruction process.

Latest survey results indicate that 53% of survey respondents feel their main reconstruction needs are being met, and 76% of respondents feel they have the information they need to access support and/or services.

# local risk identification mechanisms have discussed potential or actual issues that may affect social cohesion # of initiatives taken for mitigating conflict related risks at local level

comment.narrative: NA

#400 women and youth people from marginalized groups capacitated in peacebuilding dialogue and social cohesion # 12 inclusive community security plans developed # 50 Early response initiatives for emerging tensions taken by political parties and other stakeholders in program districts # 2 Peace structures formed or strengthened for promoting social cohesion

All the above target achived in 2016.
The project successfully piloted micro-grant facility for community-based organizations and completed 12 quick impact projects (in 7 program districts) that brought together marginalized groups with history of hostilities and mistrusts for mutually beneficial collective actions such as livelihood activities and facilitating access to government services. Encouraged from this success of engaging communities for social cohesion, the SCDP will upscale the micro-grant facility in 2017.
Mechanisms supported by this project contributed for timely and effective community acts to mitigate emerging risks and consolidating social cohesion by moderating and neutralizing inter-religious and inter-ethnic tensions between ethnic and ideological groups. For instance, on the request of Kanchanpur DDC, the Multi-Stakeholder Dialogue Forum resolved a natural resource based dispute. Locals from Krishnapur and Dekhatbhuli VDCs of Kanchanpur district have been in bitter disagreement regarding the ownership of a pond that touches both the VDCs, which adversely impacted the social harmony.
Nearly 4000 youths, women, marginalized groups, civil society members, government officials, political leaders and journalists involved in promotion of social cohesion through 81 community level initiatives. More than 2000 people (37% Female and 63% Male), including youth and representatives of excluded groups, acquired basic skills on approaches to promoting social cohesion.
SCDP was able to maintain a high degree of womens participation in the events it organized. Womens participation in events organized to discuss issues related to social cohesion and community security was maintained at 33% across the 12 project districts. Similarly, events organized exclusively on womens human security issues and inclusion the participation of women was maintained at 70%.
At least 12 risk identification mechanisms initiatied 60 initiatives taken to mitigate the conflict related risks at the local level

The project conducted risk/conflict analysis on a regular basis that informed risk mitigation process. This was done through regular interactions and meetings with key actors (political, social, religious, civil society leaders, community members, women and the marginalized communities etc) through risk identification mechanism. There are more than 30 risk identification mechanism in place in 10 programme districts.
There are more than 60 initiatives taken in order to mitigate the risk of conflict. This year 27 micro capital grants were provided at the community level to help mitigate conflict risks. These grants included livelihood initiatives in the mixed communities to help promote an environment where people from diverse background get opportunity to work together, there were grants to promote youth volunteerism to promote peace and harmony, grants to enhance access to basis services and accontability and grants to strengthen community security to promote social cohesion.
Similarly, two rounds of programme were organized in 10 programme districts in order to promote peaceful elections (this was done during i. local election and ii. provincial and federal election). This included orientation and workshop with the key actors (political party leaders, civil society leaders, youth, women, media, government officials, religious leaders) who were engaged in identifying the risk of election related violence and mitigating/preventing violence when necessary.

comment.narrative:
As of 2012, disaster risk management is not part of the regular national training programme for Government staffs.
As of 2012, the building permit process in all municipalities in Nepal is paper-based.

(1) Formulate National DRR Policy and Strategic Action Plan in line with Sendai Framework of DRR (SFDRR) (2) Prepare mainstreaming guideline for DRR-CCA (3) Document the learning of Gorkha EQ (4) Capacity building training for safer building construction (5) Strength/establish DEOC

1. Formulation of National DRR Policy and Strategic Action Plan in line with Sendai Framework of DRR (SFDRR) initiated under leadership of the Ministry of Home Affairs (MoHA).
2. A mainstreaming guideline for DRR-CCA has been drafted under leadership of the National Planning Commission.
3. "Gorkha Earthquake 2015 Response: Learning and Experience" has been documented and a video documentary developed.
4.Over 500 masons including 25 women and 111 engineers (trainers) have been trained to facilitate reconstructions in EQ affected districts.
5. Additional Four District Emergency Operation Centers (DEOCs) were established, one each in Gorkha, Rasuwa, Nuwakot and Solukhumbu, resulting into national network of 56 EOCs.
(6) For community based early warning system in Maadi, Chitwan, 5 Automatic hydrological and meteorological stations were established at different locations: Bankatta, Chharchare, Kalyanpur, Govindabasti and Thori.
(7) Implementation of building code further strengthened in municipalities of Kathmandu Valley and National Building Code implementation started in 3 municipalities namely Chautara, Melamchi and Panchkhal municipalities .

(1) National DRR Policy and Strategic Action Plan prepared in line with Sendai Framework 2015-2030 under leadership of the Ministry of Home Affairs.
(2) DRR-CCA Mainstreaming guidelines developed under leadership of National Planning Commission

(1) National Policy and Strategic Action Plan for DRR have been developed under the leadership of the Ministry of Home Affairs (MoHA) and in consultation with all DRR stakeholders including donors/ development partners and other stakeholders including I/NGOs and DPNet. The policy and action plans were developed through rigorous consultative process at district/sub-national and national levels. 7 district level consultations, one in each of the seven provinces and 3 regional level consultations were held during the formulation.
(2) Disaster Risk Reduction and Climate Change Adaptation (DRR-CCA) mainstreaming guideline has been prepared under the leadership of National Planning Commission (NPC). The guideline was finalized incorporating feedback from national district consultations (Dolakha and Mahottari) followed by the final consultations with the concerned ministries. The guideline has been further enriched and harmonized with Nepal Constitution 2015, Unbundling report, DRRM Act 2017, Local Government Operation Act 2017, Draft National DRR Policy and Strategic Action Plan and SDGs priorities. The guideline is expected to support ministries, province and local government to be able to integrate DRR CCA actions into sectoral local development plan to make the upcoming national local plan risk informed.

comment.narrative: No NBC implementation in KV 0 municipalities (2014) Very less awareness outside KV Inadequate engineers/masons trained 8 municipalities, KMC and LSMC in KV. none outside KV by 2015
(1) Establish Electronic Building Permit System (eBPS)

(1) Lalitpur Sub-metropolitan city and Kirtipur municipality have successfully established the Electronic Building Permit System (eBPS) and formally launched implementation of eBPS in their jurisdiction. Kathmandu was the first to launch in 2015.

(1) National Building Codes (NBC) implementation established in the three municipalities (Panchkhal of Kavre and Chautara and Melamchi of Sindhupalchowk). RSLUP of Chautara municipality approved. (GoJ funded project)
(2) Technical support provided in 10 VDCs (5 each in Sindhupalchowk and Dolakha) for safer reconstruction through technology demonstration, VDC level Reconstruction Action Plan and community awareness raising activities. (ECHO funded project)
(3) Around 10000 people from Gorkha, Sindhupalchowk and Dolakha aware on safer reconstruction through organizing Mobile Technological Clinics (MTC).

(1) The three municipalities- Panchkhal (Kavre), Chautara (Sindhupalchowk) and Melamchi (Sindhupalchowk) have established National Building Code compliant building permit system. The three municipalities have issued 230 building permits in first quarter of 2017 out of the total 440 permits issued during project period. Chautara Municipality has approved Risk Sensitive Land Use Plan (RSLUP), and updated its Building Bye-laws based on the RSLUP
(2) 65 Technology Demonstration Houses (TDHs) have been constructed, in the ten VDCs,: i) brick in cement masonry and ii) stone in mud masonry with GI wires containment technologies in each municipality. Altogether 1082 women were oriented during the project period. About 500 people, 33% women, were oriented through weekly orientation and community orientation programme. Altogether, over 1246 people were oriented in the three municipalities during the project period. Likewise, 1818 people oriented through community awareness program during the project period.
(3) Awareness raising campaigns through Mobile Technological Clinics (MTC): Awareness raising activities for safer house construction at rural level were conducted in various VDCs and municipalities in Sindhupalchowk, Gorkha and Dolakha districts. During Jan-Dec 2017, about 13,765 people (approximately 40% women) were oriented in 2 districts through the MTC initiative. In addition, about 1300 people were oriented through organizing 18 MTC campaigns in Gorkha districts as well.

(1) More than 20000 house owners/farmers have been oriented on earthquake safe house (re)construction in over 115 VDCs of Gorkha, Sindhupalchowk, Gorkha.
(2) Four technologies for rural housing reconstruction have been demonstration: (i) GI contained stone masonry building, (ii) Compressed Stabilized Earthen Block (CSEB) have been demonstrated in Gorkha, (iii) Upcycled Debris Block preparation and (iv) Re-clustering approach for settlements vulnerable to natural hazards.

(1) National Early Recovery Framework (ER Framework) finalized under leadership of MoFALD.
(2) Gaps in Disaster Information Management system identified and DMIS modified under leadership of MoHA.

(1) A national Early Recovery workshop has also been organized in developing clarity on ER related issues such as on conceptual clarity, the ER approach, coordination mechanism and roles and responsibilities, under MoFALD leadership.
(2) Under this initiative a wider national consultation workshop on Disaster Information Management System (DMIS) was organized, gap identified and DMIS modified accordingly.

comment.narrative: No Local Adaptation Plan of Action Implemented.

(1) Implementation of 512 local adaptation plan of actions (2) Organise orientation and trainings to district/VDC/municipality stakeholders on CCA, GESI and M/E (69 events) (3) Continued support to MoPE in policy and international commitment areas (NAP, INDC, Climate Financing)

(1) 732 prioritized local adaptation plan of actions implemented in 87 VDCs and 9 municipalities of 14 districts in far and mid-western region of Nepal benefitting 180,164 people. 890 metallic stoves and 1510 improved cooking stoves were distributed to the 2400 poor and vulnerable households. 45,910 meters of irrigation canals were constructed and maintained covering altogether 158 sites, irrigating additional 744.7 hectares of land. 15 plastic ponds, 64 rain water harvesting tanks, 406 normal ponds with a total capacity over 1.91 million litres were built to conserve water for irrigation purposes as well as household uses. 538 drinking water taps and 225 drinking water tanks with 912,197 litres of water storage capacity were built to serve additional 4,522 households to access clean water facilities. 34 elevated taps, 10 elevated toilets and 2 elevated safe grounds were built in flood prone areas.
(2) Orientation and training to district / VDC /municipality stakeholders on CCA, GESI and M/E (69 events) organised (3) Support provided to Ministry of Population and Environment in policy and international commitment areas (NAP, INDC, Climate Financing)

(1) 257 adaptation actions implemented in areas of (i) agriculture, livestock, food security (ii) forest management and bio-diversity (iii) climate-induced hazard/physical infrastructure (iv)human resource, capacity development
(2) Training focused on financial management, Public Procurement Act, financial reporting, audit, organized for GoN/local level officials including the project staff completed
(3) Comprehensive document highlighting the key leverage areas through independent study of the programme intervention prepared
(4) LCCAF fund established in 14 districts

(1) 248 adaptation actions implemented in areas of (i) agriculture, livestock, food security (ii) forest management and bio-diversity (iii) climate-induced hazard/physical infrastructure (iv)human resource, capacity development.
(2) Training conducted covering financial management, Public Procurement Act, financial reporting, audit, organized for GoN/local level officials including the project staff.
(3) An independent study conducted and different success and learning cases documented
(4) 104 Local Adaptation Funds established in 14 districts to address urgent and immediate issues of climate change impact. They also address climate issues of emergency nature.

comment.narrative: More than 31,862 people live in the high risk settlements of Imja GLOF Impact Zone and are directly vulnerable to GLOF impacts. They have no EWS. Other forms of disaster preparedness are also limited.

1: Controlled drainage to reduce lake water by 3 meters in the Imja Glacial Lake completed. 2: Automated GLOF early warning system installed and made operational which will support to institutionalize the information dissemination of GLOF warnings and climate induced disasters through DHM website; institutionalization of Task forces and operationalization of community based early warning systems 3: Construction of embankment in five river basins and strengthening of evacuation centers in three targeted districts will be completed in Terai working districts. 4: Awareness raising activities on flood preparedness and institutionalization of knowledge products through collaborating partners including capacity building of Community Disaster Management Committees and Village Disaster Risk Management Committees undertaken.

description.narrative: To reduce human and material losses from Glacier Lake Outburst Flooding GLOF in Solukhumbu District and catastrophic flooding events in the Tarai and Churia Range

Number of high risk settlements of the GLOF Impact Zone of Solukhumbu district downstream of Imja lake area covered by an Early Warning System EWS refer to AMAT 1212
Number of institutions with increased capacity to minimize human and material losses from potential GLOF events in the High Mountains and climaterelated flooding in the Tarai and Churia Range refer to AMAT 221

comment.narrative:
As per the updated Baseline developed by the project Within 50 km downstream from the Imja Glacial Lake mainly covering 4 VDCs among which Khumjung Namche Chaurikharka lies in SNP Buffer Zone and adjoining Juving VDC which lies outside the buffer zone are identified as vulnerable VDCs Altogether 40 settlements having 3278 households with 12690 population which lie in 4 VDCs were identified as vulnerable from Imja GLOF
Primary beneficiaries 4360 population residing in permanent settlements with critical risk of GLOF
Secondary Beneficiaries 12690 residing along 50 km downstream from Imja Lake in 40 permanent settlements This includes the 4360 primary beneficiaries as well
Tertiary Beneficiaries Annual floating population 74992 24994 tourist 49998 porters and VDC people residing along the trekking route and Imja Khola and Dudhkoshi River
Total Beneficiaries A total of 87682 population including permanent residents and annual floating population in the area
The initial estimation of total beneficiaries was only 31862 However the study conducted by project on GLOF Hazard Zonation and Safety Evacuation Plan explored that the total of 87682 people will be benefited from the GLOF risk reduction activities in Khumbu region Thus project will be using the updated data instead of the numbers reported in project document
Infrastructure 55 km road 94 km trail 25 truss and suspension bridges 05 river embankment 05 irrigation canal three schools four office buildings 137 hotels 64 teashops three temple gumba and mosque two hydropower dam five water mills seven transmission lines and one industry
Total direct indirect costs of potential GLOF damages including replacement of major infrastructure estimated as 898 billion
Weak system for flood risk management only construction work is done in DWIDP
There is only a district level Disaster Relief Committee though no GLOF risk management committee formed in Solukhumbu district
DDRC is mostly involved in rescue and relief for post disaster work and their activity in the targeted districts is limited
Limited trained staff in DHM to work in GLOF risk reduction

By the end of the project at least 100 of the population men and women who are directly vulnerable to GLOF impacts within the 27 high risk settlements GLOF Impact Zone are covered by a comprehensive CommunityBased Early Warning System CBEWS
By the end of the project targeted trainingon the job training in gender sensitive flood risk management including disaster preparedness will have been provided to at least 32 technical staff from 2 key government departments DHM 2 senior level and DWIDP 30 district and regional level 30 representatives from 5 DDRCs 64 representatives from 1 GLOF Risk Management Committee and at least 2 university students
DHM will have the necessary technologies skills systems to assess and effectively communicate GLOF risk levels and warnings
DWIDP will have the necessary technologies skills systems to monitor sediment load in floodprone river basins in the Tarai Churia Range
The Annual District Plans of at least 3 of the 5 target project districts incorporate budgeted flood risk preparedness activities

Twelve Taskforces each containing three subgroups of search and rescue first aid and early warning have been formed during March 2015 in project area All Taskforces have been equipped with necessary First Aid FA Light Search and Rescue LSAR and Community Based Early Warning System CBEWS equipment and trained total 152 members on use of equipment during GLOF and any climatic hazards on June 2015
CBEWS have been installed in 15 identified locations along the 50 km stretch downstream from Imja during June 2015
First round of training on Flood Risk Management and Sediment Monitoring was organized during 1821 August 2014 at Lahan for district level officers Another training was organized during 1720 November 2014 for national level officials As a followup of first round training on Flood risk management and sediment monitoring is planned for third quarter 2015
Sediment Monitoring Protocols for Churia Originating River Systems was developed and shared to DHM DWIDP and DSCMW which aims toward internalizing the Protocols in their sediment database management system

Water supplydrainage system in 8 VDCs gets flooded making it difficult for 59062 population

There are no EWS in the 4 project target districts 3 VDCs Mahisthan Hattilet and Aurahi communities in Mahottari district Janagha River have been trained in CBEWS UNDPCDRMP programme
The total population of the most floodprone VDCs is 59062
Weak system for flood risk management DWIDP currently focuses only on construction works
Limited trained staffs in DWIDP on flood risk management
DDRC is mostly involved in rescue and relief for post disaster work and their activity in the targeted districts is limited

At least 70 population in 3 districts6 VDCs have access to 24 elevated tube wells andor a flood proofing drainage system
100 of the population covered by CBEWS in all target flood prone river basins

35 Elevated Tube Wells were constructed in the four districts8 target VDCs Hence this ensures about 75 population have access to safe drinking water during flood
About 45 km long Flood Proofing Drainage System has been constructed by the end of June 2015
Total of eight Village Disaster Risk Management Committees VDRMCs and 35 Community Disaster Management Committees CDMCs have been formed and operationalized during July 2014 A total of 399 members are affiliated in 35 CDMCs including 200 female and 199 male
Altogether 28 FA Taskforces and 27 LSAR Taskforces have been formed under CDMCs and operationalized during July 2014 Likewise 23 CBEWS Taskforces have been formed during March 2015
Taskforces were equipped with relevant equipment during March 2015
Training on LSAR and FA to members of Taskforces have been conducted during June 2015 A total of 213 members were trained including 87 female
A total of 44 District and national level officials from DWIDP and DSCWM have been trained on Flood Risk Management Sediment Monitoring during August and November 2014 respectively
Training on Mainstreaming Flood Risk Management in Development Planning Process was also conducted to VDC level officials during August 2014

Target 1: Study on staffing and organizational inter linkages in at least 4 sectors completed Target 2: Support to conduct study on financial decentralization and support to task force secretariat of high level committee of FIARCC Target 3: Sectoral Transition management plan supported

Result 1: Institutional re-arrangement study in four major sectors was initiated.UNDP support to carry out a study on organizational structure in all the 3 tiers of the government along with the tentative HR requirements for health, agriculture, transportation and education sectors was instrumental to equip the senior government officials representing a number of ministries and departments including some commissions. Result 2: UNDP support to carry out a study on fiscal decentralization was used as a reference document to determine the boundaries and numbers of the local government bodies by the High Level Federalization/Decentralization Committee, FIARCC, MOFALD and Ministry of Finance. UNDP supported Ministry of General administration in designing national policy/strategy for restructuring of civil service in the federal structure. Result 3: UNDP also supported the government to develop draft transition management plan for administrative restructuring.

To undertake the functional analysis in five thematic clusters covering all existing sectors of government functions as per the new constitution
To conduct a study on inter-governmental fiscal transfer and provide inputs to concerned ministries in preparing laws

UNDP supported the Office of the Prime Minister in detailing out the constitutionally defined roles and responsibilities of the three levels of government to further clarify them through a functional analysis exercise . The detailed-out roles have become a part of the Local Government Operation Act for which UNDP provided technical inputs throughout the process.
UNDP provided technical inputs into the Inter-Governmental Fiscal Management Act which is akin to framework law applicable to all three levels of government. Detail study was carried out on inter-government fiscal transfer and its recommendations being referred by different ministries I developing a law.

1. Support the capacity development efforts along with the policy support and overall implementation of the TSNGP through the Program Coordination Unit (PCU) at the federal level and seven Provincial Support Units (PSUs) in the provinces. 2. meet the coordination and quality assurance needs of the TSNGP.

The Policy and Programme Support Facility (PPSF), under the UN Joint Programme (UNJP) comprising of UNDP, UNCDF and UNV is proving Technical Assistance (TA) to the Local Governance and Community Development Programme (LGCDP)-Transition to Sub National Governance Programme (TSNGP), a national flagship programme of the Ministry of Federal Affairs and Local Development (MoFALD). UNDP's technical assistance focused on policy research and capacity development for service delivery, coordination and oversight mechanisms. The Programme Coordination Unit (PCU) at the centre and seven Provincial Support Units (PSUs) provided technical backstopping to MoFALD and local bodies (now local governments) for the program implementation, coordination, monitoring and reporting.
.Provided orientation and training programmes to 733 Chief Administrative Officers from seven provinces and 73 LDOs on local government operational issues through Policy and Programme Support Facility (PPSF). Likewise, UNDP provided support to manage and facilitate orientation programme for newly elected Mayors, Deputy Mayors, Chairs and Vice Chairs of local governments of the provinces no. 1, 2, 3, 4 and 6. The PPSF also supported other capacity building initiatives such as experience sharing workshop on Fiscal Federalism, induction training to LGCDP II focal persons, training on Appreciative Inquiry and Theory of Change to all LGCDP staff, regional consultative meeting, MToT and Orientation Programme on Local Government Operation and Management, workshop for the development of Website for rural municipalities, etc. These initiatives contributed to strengthen capacity of the elected representatives, local level staff and LGCDP staff working at central and provincial levels which is one of the priority areas of LGCDP-TSNGP.

description.narrative: The planned outcomes on completion are (a) 2012 Technical Vocational Education and Training (TVET) policy implemented; and (b) TVET provision is monitored and evaluated.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: The support will be provided for Ministry of Education and Council for Technical Education and Vocational Training (CTEVT).

description.narrative:
I) Inclusive TVET policy revised and prepared with participation of various stakeholders (the Ministry of Education, other ministries, private sector, donors, and training providers) in place, approved and implementation started.
II) (a) national system in place for the coordinated planning and assessment of TVET provisions; (b) basis for dealing with excess demand and requalification determined; (c) TVET publications

comment.narrative:
I) There is consensus on the quality of 2012 TVET policy, but also widespread recognition in government and amongst the development partners that there has been limited progress in its implementation.
II) Fragmentation of TVET provision (with many ministries and other public organisation providing TVET) and absence of any overarching ME system in the subsector.

Activity Result 1: Policy dialogue established and instituted on a regular basis with stakeholders (continue)
Activity Result 2: Proposals for how to engage the private sector (businesses, industry and training providers) in TVET policy development, planning and implementation.
Activity Result 3: TVET actions assessment system in place
Activity Result 4: TVET Publication of national and international significance
Activity result 5: Establishment of labor market signaling system (continuation)
Activity Result 6: Programme Monitoring and Knowledge management (continuation)

Activity Result 1: Guidelines for establishing institutionalized Policy Dialogue Process in TVET developed and endorsed by Technical Committee under Policy Coordination Committee, Ministry of Education. Orientations and preparatory works on TVET policy dialogue process completed with 18 TVET related ministries at joint secretary level, executive members of FNCCI, FNCSI and other major employer associations.
Activity Result 2: Proposal for engaging private sector in TEVT provisions completed with the wider involvement of representatives of business and industry. The assignment has been performed by FNCCI with the financial and technical support from SKILLS.
Activity Result 3: SKILLS prepared methodology of impact evaluation of TVET programme, and developed web based national MIS database system to improve the quality of TVET programmes and services in the country.
Activity Result 4: The progrmme prepared TVET comprehensive annual report in order to disseminate the overall outcomes of the TVET programmes and services at yearly basis.
Activity Result 5: SKILLS programme completed labour market assessment in agriculture trade, prepared methodology of impact evaluation of TVET programme, prepared TVET comprehensive annual report, developed web based national MIS database system to improve the quality of TVET programmes and services in the country.
Activity Result 6: SKILLS programme initiated the Knowledge Management and Networking System with multiple stakeholders including TVET related ministries, private training providers, and business and industry at regional and central level in close collaboration and partnership with the CTEVT.

Activity Result 1: Policy dialogue established and instituted on a regular basis with stakeholders (continue) Activity Result 2: Coordinated planning and strengthen monitoring and evaluation of TVET provision Activity Result 3: TVET actions assessment system in place

Activity Result 1: SKILLS programme continued to conduct policy dialogues among TVET stakeholders, and established and instituted policy dialogues on a regular basis with stakeholders at federal, provincial and local levels. Activity Result 2: Supported to the Ministry of Education and established TVET monitoring and evaluation system. Now, the data synchronization of development partners have been completed, and CTEVT data synchronization is in progress.
Activity Result 3: SKILLS supported to the Ministry of Education to design and implement ME system for assessing TVET provisions. Activity result 4: Published TVET Annual Report in 2017 on the TVET national significance that covers the contributions of the Government line agencies and development partners in TVET development in Nepal. Action 5: Establishment of labour market signaling system: SKILLS programme carried out the labour market assessment in agriculture trade and developed methodology of impact evaluation of TVET programme to address the needs of market Activity Result 6: Programme Monitoring and Knowledge management (continuation): SKILLS programme organized a series of joint monitoring visits in Chitwan, Hetauda and several other districts in 2017.

description.narrative:
"% of registered cases that are investigated by Transitional justice mechanisms in line with international standards (UNDAF 1 #8.1.2) Alternative Indicator: # of victims of gross human rights violations during the conflict who receive compensation (UNDAF 8.1.3)" # of victims of gross human rights violations during the conflict who receive comprehensive reparative benefits and services (UNDAF 1 #8.1.3) Action plan for the TJ mechanism developed and implemented # of women victims trained on women's engagement in the truth telling process
The Truth and Reconciliation Commission and Commission for the Investigation of Disappeared Persons have been established in February 2015 but yet to be fully functional.

comment.narrative: Neither Truth and Reconciliation Commission nor Commission of Inquiry on Disappearances established as of July 2012. Draft reparations policy and proposed reparations programme submitted to government 80 women leaders oriented on TJ and truth telling process
Target 1: Establishment of Victim Centric Transitional Justice Resource Centre(TJRC) Target 2: Organization of International Conference on truth telling to conflict victims and CVCP members

Result 1: UNDP launched the Transitional Justice Resource Center (TJRC) in March 2016. The TJRC has been providing space for conflict victims to come together, discuss their issues and concern and plan advocacy events. Result 2: UNDP organized a conference on unofficial truth telling to provide civil society groups in TJ an opportunity to hear the experiences of experts in unofficial truth seeking measures

Target 1: To enhance capacity and strengthen leadership qualities of the members of Conflict Victims Common Platform (CVCP) Target 2: To enhance knowledge of mainstream media about different facets of transitional justice processes and to support building relationship of victims network with the media personnel

Result 1: Members of the victim network have enhanced self and social awareness for leadership, with increased analytical ability around key issues on gender, sex, patriarchy, power and leadership, and strengthened ability to communicate in a compelling manner. This was achieved through capacity building training and workshops organized for the CVCP members.
Result 2: Increased quality reporting on Transitional Justice processes and increased collaboration between victims' network and media personnel. This year a virtual platform is established TRC Reporting Group in messenger where information is shared among reporters and victim leaders. This has helped the accuracy and quality of reporting on transitional justice issues

1. UNDP recovery strategy with RRF prepared. After Action Review conducted and lessons learned were fed into UNDP's corporate policy and practice for crisis response.Project proposals developed for resource mobilization.
2. Three institutional documents developed: i) NRA's Communication and Media Strategy and Action Plan; ii) NRA Organizational Review and HR Needs Assessment; iii) NRA HR Strategy Plan. Strong partnership maintained with NRA.
3. PDRF institutionalized with strong ownership of Government including localization of PDRF in 14 districts. Guidance note for Integrating DRR, RR and GESI in the Periodic District Development Plan (PDDP) prepared by MoFALD and approved by NPC and NRA with the technical support from UNDP. After the ToT to the senior officials (35) from NRA/ MoFALD and NPC, District level stakeholders (Government counterparts, political parties, I/NGOs/DPs) of 14 earthquake affected districts and 1 Municipality were trained and oriented on integrating RR, DRR and GESI in Periodic District Development Plan (PDDP); The trainings were jointly facilitated by MoFALD, NRA and UNDP. Altogether 1,022 individuals were trained through 15 training events. Partnership strengthened with DFID and JICA for technical backstopping to DDCs while preparing PDDP in 5 districts supported by DFID (3 districts: Dhading, Nuwakoat and Rasuwa) and JICA (2 districts: Gorkha and Sindhupalchowk). Action plans prepared and approved by the local authorities to integrate the RR and DRR in the PDDP.
4. DACFC, high level development assistance coordination mechanism established and operational. District level coordination mechanism established and is operational in 4 districts (Dolakha, Gorkha, Sindhupalchowk, Kavre). NRA Advisory Committee approved DACFC in Oct 2016 and UNDP provides technical support to NRA DACFC Secretariat. Two DACFC meetings have been conducted by the end of 4th quarter. Livelihoods Working Group established and operational at 2 districts (Sindhup

1. 2 new recovery projects formulated and action plans implemented to improve capacity in crisis response and recovery programming
2. At least 2 institutional documents developed and strong partnership maintained with NRA.
3. PDRF institutionalized Annual Action Plans developed after integrating DRR, Recovery and Reconstruction priorities and budget for 14-earthquake affected districts
4. 1 National and 14 district level coordination mechanism established and is operational through NRA
5. Emergency response at flood affected districts benefitting 4000 HHs from free animal health camps; 18000 HHs from seed distribution, 1500 HHs from livestock restocking, 113,089 community people from the rehabilitation of 36 critical community infrastructures, 1828 local people through cash for work

1. Altogether 4 projects formulated and operational. Among them 1 is focused on supporting NRA on resilient reconstruction at earthquake affected districts while 3 for emergency flood response. The project contributed to CPD formulation (2018-2022) and action plans to improve capacity in crisis response and recovery programming.
2. All together 3 institutional documents prepared for NRA and strong partnership maintained with NRA through technical and operational support. Altogether 27 District Support Engineers (DSEs) and 17 technical experts were mobilized to accelerate recovery and reconstruction projects. The experts were particularly deployed for recovery coordination, human resource management, communication and media, legal provision, budget tracking, access to finance, NGO coordination, GIS, information management, housing reconstruction, technical coordination in order to make sure that the reconstruction process is effective and well coordinated.
3. PDRF finalized and institutionalized through MoFALD and NRA. The process of localizing PDRF has been initiated through 6 events of orientations/ trainings to senior officials and political representatives of 6 municipalities of Nuwakot, Ramechhap, Dolakha, Sindhupalchok, Kavrepalanchok and Lalitpur districts (one municipality in each district) to integrate DRR/ CCA, Recovery and Resilience and GESI in their Annual Municipal Development Plans.
4. National coordination mechanism established and operational through Development Assistance Coordination Facilitation Committee (DACFC), led by NRA. UNDP continues to provide information management and livelihoods recovery coordination support in Sindhupalchowk, Kavre, Gorkha and Dolakha districts. The process of integrating UNDP's District Coordination support to NRA District Office has initiated.
5. Post Flood Recovery Needs Assessment (PFRNA) report published and launched by NPC on 1 December 2017. Through the implementation of flood recovery projects, 4000 HH

description.narrative: Green Climate Fund Readiness in Nepal that aims to support the GoN. UNDP components of the project will mainly contribute to build core institutional capacity of the NDA to access, absorb, and manage climate finance.
capital of a political entity

1. Core institutional capacity building- a) At least 3 trainings to understand the roles and responsibilities of GCF NDA and relevant MoF staffs; while ensuring capacity for effective coordination of stakeholders and assessment/recommendation for funding proposals; b) Standard Operating Procedures, toolkit and guidelines for efficient involvement of stakeholders in GCF partnerships with GoN and c) establishment of GCF NDA secretariat at MoF 2. Investment frameworks for adaptation and mitigation options to reduce climate change induced disasters risk; a) Robust investment frameworks are in place for adaptation and mitigation options in prioritized sectors to adequately access additional resources of climate finance.

comment.narrative: 1. The MoF was nominated as NDA to GCF in 2015 and has no institutional readiness to access, absorb and manage climate finance. 2. There was no standard operating procedure developed to engaged with GCF. 3. There was no dedicated unit to look at GCF related matters at MoF.
